Award.AwardTitle: Religious Orthodoxy and New Media Technologies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Ayala Fader of Fordham University will investigate the impact of new media technologies on skepticism and protest within ultra-Orthodox religious communities. The project analyzes the practices of a community of ultra-Orthodox Jews in Brooklyn who privately question whether the Torah is the word of God, yet remain within their stringently religious communities. At the same time, these ultra-Orthodox individuals anonymously critique their communities online and secretly explore the secular world online and offline. Over the past decade, communal authority figures have increasingly blamed the Internet for this conflict, calling the current moment a "crisis of emune (faith)" and even claiming that the Internet may prove more dangerous to Jewish continuity than the Holocaust. Fader will conduct research from three perspectives: that of communal leadership who try to strengthen faith; ultra-Orthodox individuals who secretly use digital media in multiple languages (Yiddish, English and Yinglish); and in civil child custody cases when one parent has left his/her religious community. Data collection will draw on methodologies from cultural and linguistic anthropology and include online materials, audio-recordings made in ethnographic interviews, participant observation and transcription with community consultants.

The project contributes to research on conflict and change within ultra-Orthodox religious communities in the digital age. The focus is the consequences for those who lose faith in a nonliberal religious belief, yet simultaneously reject secularism. In a world increasingly polarized by religion, the project interrogates a case study, which blurs the boundaries between belief and doubt, morality and immorality, the secular and the religious.

The project aims to provoke conversations between the academy and the public about contemporary religion, morality and digital media. Dissemination and pedagogical impact will include student training, conference presentations, publications and presentations to local community groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Religious Orthodoxy and New Media Technologies asks what a crisis of authority among ultra-Orthodox Jews in New York can tell us about religious doubt and social change in the digital age. The subjects are ultra-Orthodox men and women who no longer believed the Torah to be God’s words to the chosen people, yet who found themselves unable or unwilling to leave their families and their communities. Called “bahaltene apikorsim” (Yiddish, hidden heretics) or “double lifers,” these were men and (fewer) women who continued to live ultra-Orthodox lives, even as they explored forbidden worlds online and in person, secretly breaking the Jewish commandments. A growing awareness of this population led ultra-Orthodox leadership to call the current moment a “crisis of faith,” to turn their intention to Jewish interiors (in contrast to religious practice), and to blame the Internet for religious doubt. 

Based on five years of ethnographic fieldwork in digital and face-to-face contexts, the project followed those living double lives and those who ministered to them: rabbis, religious therapists, and religious life coaches. All came to recognize that the threat of the Internet to ultra-Orthodox religious authority was its new possibilities for interaction with like-minded others, its avenues to alternative truths, and its spaces for anonymous, yet public dissent that directly challenged ultra-Orthodoxy authority. Ultimately, the conflict over the Internet and religious doubt among the ultra-Orthodox was one piece in a bigger puzzle that centered on how to account for competing notions of persons, authority, and truth in the 21stcentury. 

The outcomes of the project include two peer-reviewed journal articles, two more popular blogposts, and a forthcoming book (spring 2020, Princeton University Press) entitled, Hidden Heretics: Jewish Doubt in the Digital Age. The publications contribute to scholarship in the anthropology of religion and media, the anthropology of morality and ethics, linguistic anthropology, and Jewish Studies. The project also developed methodological innovations to account for the research that crossed digital and face-to-face spaces. Equally important, the book speaks to a more general audience, using a particular ultra-Orthodox Jewish case to pose widely shared questions about religious faith and doubt; the impact of digital media on our minds and social lives; and moral struggles in families when one person radically transforms who they are and what they believe.
